title: Washington
text:
This is the init_notebook_mode cell from ITables v2.1.0
(you should not see this message - is your notebook trusted?)






Introduction
Welcome to the city comparison view of USASpending.gov data, that may be relevant to violence prevention for Washington.


Violence Prevention Funding vs Annual Fatal Shootings, Comparison
This display may serve as a comparison to see funding amounts for the current city (in blue) vs other cities (in green).

AllDOJDOEHUDLabor




                                                




                                                


                                                


                                                


                                                





City Comparisons
Here, we display each individual grant source and its total funding value. Then, we look at the total funding value for the closest 5 cities (absolute distance) via three metrics: average population, number of fatal shootings, and number of shootings per 100k residents.
For example, the closest 5 cities by population to Washington (which had a population of 694,741 people) were:

Indianapolis, Indiana (878,020 people)
Dallas, Texas (1,321,780 people)
New Orleans, Louisiana (387,417 people)
Saint Louis, Missouri (302,217 people)
Detroit, Michigan (655,330 people)



For the closest cities by population, we show in red the grant categories where washington is relatively under-funded, and in green, those where it is relatively over-funded.











    
      
      Grant Source
      Total Funds
      Closest 5: Avg Population
      Closest 5: Fatal Shootings
      Closest 5: Shootings/100k

title: Phoenix
text:
This is the init_notebook_mode cell from ITables v2.1.0
(you should not see this message - is your notebook trusted?)






Introduction
Welcome to the city comparison view of USASpending.gov data, that may be relevant to violence prevention for Phoenix.


Violence Prevention Funding vs Annual Fatal Shootings, Comparison
This display may serve as a comparison to see funding amounts for the current city (in blue) vs other cities (in green).

AllDOJDOEHUDLabor




                                                




                                                


                                                


                                                


                                                





City Comparisons
Here, we display each individual grant source and its total funding value. Then, we look at the total funding value for the closest 5 cities (absolute distance) via three metrics: average population, number of fatal shootings, and number of shootings per 100k residents.
For example, the closest 5 cities by population to Phoenix (which had a population of 1,629,759 people) were:

Los Angeles, California (3,934,207 people)
Columbus, Ohio (899,799 people)
Cleveland, Ohio (377,543 people)
Atlanta, Georgia (499,094 people)
Kansas City, Missouri (499,908 people)



For the closest cities by population, we show in red the grant categories where phoenix is relatively under-funded, and in green, those where it is relatively over-funded.











    
      
      Grant Source
      Total Funds
      Closest 5: Avg Population
      Closest 5: Fatal Shootings
      Closest 5: Shootings/100k

title: New Orleans
text:
This is the init_notebook_mode cell from ITables v2.1.0
(you should not see this message - is your notebook trusted?)






Introduction
Welcome to the city comparison view of USASpending.gov data, that may be relevant to violence prevention for New Orleans.


Violence Prevention Funding vs Annual Fatal Shootings, Comparison
This display may serve as a comparison to see funding amounts for the current city (in blue) vs other cities (in green).

AllDOJDOEHUDLabor




                                                




                                                


                                                


                                                


                                                





City Comparisons
Here, we display each individual grant source and its total funding value. Then, we look at the total funding value for the closest 5 cities (absolute distance) via three metrics: average population, number of fatal shootings, and number of shootings per 100k residents.
For example, the closest 5 cities by population to New Orleans (which had a population of 387,417 people) were:

Washington, District Of Columbia (694,741 people)
Indianapolis, Indiana (878,020 people)
Dallas, Texas (1,321,780 people)
Saint Louis, Missouri (302,217 people)
Milwaukee, Wisconsin (583,071 people)



For the closest cities by population, we show in red the grant categories where new orleans is relatively under-funded, and in green, those where it is relatively over-funded.











    
      
      Grant Source
      Total Funds
      Closest 5: Avg Population
      Closest 5: Fatal Shootings
      Closest 5: Shootings/100k

title: Memphis
text:
This is the init_notebook_mode cell from ITables v2.1.0
(you should not see this message - is your notebook trusted?)






Introduction
Welcome to the city comparison view of USASpending.gov data, that may be relevant to violence prevention for Memphis.


Violence Prevention Funding vs Annual Fatal Shootings, Comparison
This display may serve as a comparison to see funding amounts for the current city (in blue) vs other cities (in green).

AllDOJDOEHUDLabor




                                                




                                                


                                                


                                                


                                                





City Comparisons
Here, we display each individual grant source and its total funding value. Then, we look at the total funding value for the closest 5 cities (absolute distance) via three metrics: average population, number of fatal shootings, and number of shootings per 100k residents.
For example, the closest 5 cities by population to Memphis (which had a population of 640,289 people) were:

New York, New York (8,565,298 people)
Baltimore, Maryland (594,084 people)
Detroit, Michigan (655,330 people)
Saint Louis, Missouri (302,217 people)
Dallas, Texas (1,321,780 people)



For the closest cities by population, we show in red the grant categories where memphis is relatively under-funded, and in green, those where it is relatively over-funded.











    
      
      Grant Source
      Total Funds
      Closest 5: Avg Population
      Closest 5: Fatal Shootings
      Closest 5: Shootings/100k

title: USA DOJ Spending Analysis
text:
This is a demo website, created by the UChicago Crime Lab, to analyze DOJ grant funding to cities from USASpending.gov. This is an attempt to better understand the amount of funds being allocated to violence prevention related programs.
Please note that everything on this website is considered a first pass analysis, and should not be taken to reflect fully accurate numbers. Ongoing work is being done to analyze where there may be incorrect labeling, either over- or under-representing the true amount of funding going into these areas for the cities being considered.

Data Sources:

DOJ Grant Funding comes from USASpending.gov
Gun violence data comes from americanviolence.org



Analysis Decisions
For the sake of data transparency, we have documented several key analytical decisions made during the data processing for this dashboard.

Exclusion of State Government Grants: We excluded grants awarded to state governments, focusing instead on resources locally available to cities.
Primary Awards Inclusion: Currently, only primary awards are included. Our roadmap includes incorporating sub-award data, which will allow for more granular analysis of fund distribution by geography.
Grant Categorization: Categorization is based on the program_activities_funding_this_award and cfda_title data fields. These columns are not always present and may use inconsistent naming conventions; therefore, the categorization should be considered with caution.
Violence Prevention Determinations: The determination of whether a grant is related to violence prevention is based solely on category and does not consider the grant description. Grants may be intended for purposes other than violence prevention, as indicated in their descriptions (e.g., grants for the purchase of body-worn cameras). Future iterations will address this labeling challenge in more detail.
Data Date Ranges: The USA Spend data are based on date ranges. We exported data based on the Action Date to determine the year a grant was awarded. We included only grant entries where the action_type_description field is âNew,â thereby excluding entries labeled as âRevisionâ or âAdjustment.â
City Selection for Demonstration: For this demonstration, we selected a random set of cities with high gun violence rates. The cities displayed can be changed in future iterations.

title: Greensboro
text:
This is the init_notebook_mode cell from ITables v2.1.0
(you should not see this message - is your notebook trusted?)






Introduction
Welcome to the city comparison view of USASpending.gov data, that may be relevant to violence prevention for Greensboro.


Violence Prevention Funding vs Annual Fatal Shootings, Comparison
This display may serve as a comparison to see funding amounts for the current city (in blue) vs other cities (in green).

AllDOJDOEHUDLabor




                                                




                                                


                                                


                                                


                                                





City Comparisons
Here, we display each individual grant source and its total funding value. Then, we look at the total funding value for the closest 5 cities (absolute distance) via three metrics: average population, number of fatal shootings, and number of shootings per 100k residents.
For example, the closest 5 cities by population to Greensboro (which had a population of 296,345 people) were:

Toledo, Ohio (272,351 people)
Tucson, Arizona (543,152 people)
Newark, New Jersey (296,165 people)
Norfolk, Virginia (240,623 people)
Buffalo, New York (267,310 people)



For the closest cities by population, we show in red the grant categories where greensboro is relatively under-funded, and in green, those where it is relatively over-funded.

      Total Funds

      Closest 5: Fatal Shootings

title: Chicago
text:
This is the init_notebook_mode cell from ITables v2.1.0
(you should not see this message - is your notebook trusted?)






Introduction
Welcome to the city comparison view of USASpending.gov data, that may be relevant to violence prevention for Chicago.


Violence Prevention Funding vs Annual Fatal Shootings, Comparison
This display may serve as a comparison to see funding amounts for the current city (in blue) vs other cities (in green).

AllDOJDOEHUDLabor




                                                




                                                


                                                


                                                


                                                





City Comparisons
Here, we display each individual grant source and its total funding value. Then, we look at the total funding value for the closest 5 cities (absolute distance) via three metrics: average population, number of fatal shootings, and number of shootings per 100k residents.
For example, the closest 5 cities by population to Chicago (which had a population of 2,722,400 people) were:

Philadelphia, Pennsylvania (1,592,615 people)
Houston, Texas (2,309,887 people)
Baltimore, Maryland (594,084 people)
Memphis, Tennessee (640,289 people)
New York, New York (8,565,298 people)



For the closest cities by population, we show in red the grant categories where chicago is relatively under-funded, and in green, those where it is relatively over-funded.











    
      
      Grant Source
      Total Funds
      Closest 5: Avg Population
      Closest 5: Fatal Shootings
      Closest 5: Shootings/100k

Introduction
Welcome to the city comparison view of USASpending.gov data, that may be relevant to violence prevention for Baton Rouge.


Violence Prevention Funding vs Annual Fatal Shootings, Comparison
This display may serve as a comparison to see funding amounts for the current city (in blue) vs other cities (in green).

AllDOJDOEHUDLabor




                                                




                                                


                                                


                                                


                                                





City Comparisons
Here, we display each individual grant source and its total funding value. Then, we look at the total funding value for the closest 5 cities (absolute distance) via three metrics: average population, number of fatal shootings, and number of shootings per 100k residents.
For example, the closest 5 cities by population to Baton Rouge (which had a population of 223,520 people) were:

Albuquerque, New Mexico (562,111 people)
Charlotte, North Carolina (874,624 people)
Oakland, California (433,089 people)
Fort Worth, Texas (909,824 people)
Cincinnati, Ohio (306,761 people)



For the closest cities by population, we show in red the grant categories where baton rouge is relatively under-funded, and in green, those where it is relatively over-funded.











    
      
      Grant Source
      Total Funds
      Closest 5: Avg Population
      Closest 5: Fatal Shootings
      Closest 5: Shootings/100k

title: Atlanta
text:
This is the init_notebook_mode cell from ITables v2.1.0
(you should not see this message - is your notebook trusted?)






Introduction
Welcome to the city comparison view of USASpending.gov data, that may be relevant to violence prevention for Atlanta.


Violence Prevention Funding vs Annual Fatal Shootings, Comparison
This display may serve as a comparison to see funding amounts for the current city (in blue) vs other cities (in green).

AllDOJDOEHUDLabor




                                                




                                                


                                                


                                                


                                                





City Comparisons
Here, we display each individual grant source and its total funding value. Then, we look at the total funding value for the closest 5 cities (absolute distance) via three metrics: average population, number of fatal shootings, and number of shootings per 100k residents.
For example, the closest 5 cities by population to Atlanta (which had a population of 499,094 people) were:

Cleveland, Ohio (377,543 people)
Kansas City, Missouri (499,908 people)
Phoenix, Arizona (1,629,759 people)
Los Angeles, California (3,934,207 people)
Columbus, Ohio (899,799 people)



For the closest cities by population, we show in red the grant categories where atlanta is relatively under-funded, and in green, those where it is relatively over-funded.











    
      
      Grant Source
      Total Funds
      Closest 5: Avg Population
      Closest 5: Fatal Shootings
      Closest 5: Shootings/100k

title: Baltimore
text:
This is the init_notebook_mode cell from ITables v2.1.0
(you should not see this message - is your notebook trusted?)






Introduction
Welcome to the city comparison view of USASpending.gov data, that may be relevant to violence prevention for Baltimore.


Violence Prevention Funding vs Annual Fatal Shootings, Comparison
This display may serve as a comparison to see funding amounts for the current city (in blue) vs other cities (in green).

AllDOJDOEHUDLabor




                                                




                                                


                                                


                                                


                                                





City Comparisons
Here, we display each individual grant source and its total funding value. Then, we look at the total funding value for the closest 5 cities (absolute distance) via three metrics: average population, number of fatal shootings, and number of shootings per 100k residents.
For example, the closest 5 cities by population to Baltimore (which had a population of 594,084 people) were:

Memphis, Tennessee (640,289 people)
New York, New York (8,565,298 people)
Houston, Texas (2,309,887 people)
Detroit, Michigan (655,330 people)
Saint Louis, Missouri (302,217 people)



For the closest cities by population, we show in red the grant categories where baltimore is relatively under-funded, and in green, those where it is relatively over-funded.











    
      
      Grant Source
      Total Funds
      Closest 5: Avg Population
      Closest 5: Fatal Shootings
      Closest 5: Shootings/100k

title: Birmingham
text:
This is the init_notebook_mode cell from ITables v2.1.0
(you should not see this message - is your notebook trusted?)






Introduction
Welcome to the city comparison view of USASpending.gov data, that may be relevant to violence prevention for Birmingham.


Violence Prevention Funding vs Annual Fatal Shootings, Comparison
This display may serve as a comparison to see funding amounts for the current city (in blue) vs other cities (in green).

AllDOJDOEHUDLabor




                                                




                                                


                                                


                                                


                                                





City Comparisons
Here, we display each individual grant source and its total funding value. Then, we look at the total funding value for the closest 5 cities (absolute distance) via three metrics: average population, number of fatal shootings, and number of shootings per 100k residents.
For example, the closest 5 cities by population to Birmingham (which had a population of 205,718 people) were:

Jacksonville, Florida (928,240 people)
San Antonio, Texas (1,481,669 people)
Columbus, Ohio (899,799 people)
Los Angeles, California (3,934,207 people)
Oakland, California (433,089 people)



For the closest cities by population, we show in red the grant categories where birmingham is relatively under-funded, and in green, those where it is relatively over-funded.











    
      
      Grant Source
      Total Funds
      Closest 5: Avg Population
      Closest 5: Fatal Shootings
      Closest 5: Shootings/100k

title: Detroit
text:
This is the init_notebook_mode cell from ITables v2.1.0
(you should not see this message - is your notebook trusted?)






Introduction
Welcome to the city comparison view of USASpending.gov data, that may be relevant to violence prevention for Detroit.


Violence Prevention Funding vs Annual Fatal Shootings, Comparison
This display may serve as a comparison to see funding amounts for the current city (in blue) vs other cities (in green).

AllDOJDOEHUDLabor




                                                




                                                


                                                


                                                


                                                





City Comparisons
Here, we display each individual grant source and its total funding value. Then, we look at the total funding value for the closest 5 cities (absolute distance) via three metrics: average population, number of fatal shootings, and number of shootings per 100k residents.
For example, the closest 5 cities by population to Detroit (which had a population of 655,330 people) were:

Saint Louis, Missouri (302,217 people)
Dallas, Texas (1,321,780 people)
Indianapolis, Indiana (878,020 people)
Washington, District Of Columbia (694,741 people)
New Orleans, Louisiana (387,417 people)



For the closest cities by population, we show in red the grant categories where detroit is relatively under-funded, and in green, those where it is relatively over-funded.











    
      
      Grant Source
      Total Funds
      Closest 5: Avg Population
      Closest 5: Fatal Shootings
      Closest 5: Shootings/100k

title: Kansas City
text:
This is the init_notebook_mode cell from ITables v2.1.0
(you should not see this message - is your notebook trusted?)






Introduction
Welcome to the city comparison view of USASpending.gov data, that may be relevant to violence prevention for Kansas City.


Violence Prevention Funding vs Annual Fatal Shootings, Comparison
This display may serve as a comparison to see funding amounts for the current city (in blue) vs other cities (in green).

AllDOJDOEHUDLabor




                                                




                                                


                                                


                                                


                                                





City Comparisons
Here, we display each individual grant source and its total funding value. Then, we look at the total funding value for the closest 5 cities (absolute distance) via three metrics: average population, number of fatal shootings, and number of shootings per 100k residents.
For example, the closest 5 cities by population to Kansas City (which had a population of 499,908 people) were:

Atlanta, Georgia (499,094 people)
Cleveland, Ohio (377,543 people)
Phoenix, Arizona (1,629,759 people)
Los Angeles, California (3,934,207 people)
Columbus, Ohio (899,799 people)



For the closest cities by population, we show in red the grant categories where kansas city is relatively under-funded, and in green, those where it is relatively over-funded.











    
      
      Grant Source
      Total Funds
      Closest 5: Avg Population
      Closest 5: Fatal Shootings
      Closest 5: Shootings/100k

title: Milwaukee
text:
This is the init_notebook_mode cell from ITables v2.1.0
(you should not see this message - is your notebook trusted?)






Introduction
Welcome to the city comparison view of USASpending.gov data, that may be relevant to violence prevention for Milwaukee.


Violence Prevention Funding vs Annual Fatal Shootings, Comparison
This display may serve as a comparison to see funding amounts for the current city (in blue) vs other cities (in green).

AllDOJDOEHUDLabor




                                                




                                                


                                                


                                                


                                                





City Comparisons
Here, we display each individual grant source and its total funding value. Then, we look at the total funding value for the closest 5 cities (absolute distance) via three metrics: average population, number of fatal shootings, and number of shootings per 100k residents.
For example, the closest 5 cities by population to Milwaukee (which had a population of 583,071 people) were:

New Orleans, Louisiana (387,417 people)
Washington, District Of Columbia (694,741 people)
Indianapolis, Indiana (878,020 people)
Dallas, Texas (1,321,780 people)
Kansas City, Missouri (499,908 people)



For the closest cities by population, we show in red the grant categories where milwaukee is relatively under-funded, and in green, those where it is relatively over-funded.

title: City Comparisons Overview
text:
Footnotes


Obligated fund amounts are aggregated over all fiscal years FY â19 - FY â24 (though FY â24 has very minimal data). Average annual fatal shootings per year take the 5-year average from American Violence, averaging from 2019-2023, then dividing by 5. American Violence also supplies the average annual population and fatal shooting per 100k rates, both across the same time period (2019-2023). Finally, Total/Violence Prevention Related Funds Per Fatal Shooting are calculated by taking the total Overall/Violence Prevention-related funding amount and dividing by the total number of fatal shootings. Since both are over a 5-year period, this averages out to total dollars per fatal shooting.â©ï¸

title: Philadelphia
text:
This is the init_notebook_mode cell from ITables v2.1.0
(you should not see this message - is your notebook trusted?)






Introduction
Welcome to the city comparison view of USASpending.gov data, that may be relevant to violence prevention for Philadelphia.


Violence Prevention Funding vs Annual Fatal Shootings, Comparison
This display may serve as a comparison to see funding amounts for the current city (in blue) vs other cities (in green).

AllDOJDOEHUDLabor




                                                




                                                


                                                


                                                


                                                





City Comparisons
Here, we display each individual grant source and its total funding value. Then, we look at the total funding value for the closest 5 cities (absolute distance) via three metrics: average population, number of fatal shootings, and number of shootings per 100k residents.
For example, the closest 5 cities by population to Philadelphia (which had a population of 1,592,615 people) were:

Houston, Texas (2,309,887 people)
Baltimore, Maryland (594,084 people)
Memphis, Tennessee (640,289 people)
New York, New York (8,565,298 people)
Chicago, Illinois (2,722,400 people)



For the closest cities by population, we show in red the grant categories where philadelphia is relatively under-funded, and in green, those where it is relatively over-funded.











    
      
      Grant Source
      Total Funds
      Closest 5: Avg Population
      Closest 5: Fatal Shootings
      Closest 5: Shootings/100k

title: Saint Louis
text:
This is the init_notebook_mode cell from ITables v2.1.0
(you should not see this message - is your notebook trusted?)






Introduction
Welcome to the city comparison view of USASpending.gov data, that may be relevant to violence prevention for Saint Louis.


Violence Prevention Funding vs Annual Fatal Shootings, Comparison
This display may serve as a comparison to see funding amounts for the current city (in blue) vs other cities (in green).

AllDOJDOEHUDLabor




                                                




                                                


                                                


                                                


                                                





City Comparisons
Here, we display each individual grant source and its total funding value. Then, we look at the total funding value for the closest 5 cities (absolute distance) via three metrics: average population, number of fatal shootings, and number of shootings per 100k residents.
For example, the closest 5 cities by population to Saint Louis (which had a population of 302,217 people) were:

Detroit, Michigan (655,330 people)
Dallas, Texas (1,321,780 people)
Indianapolis, Indiana (878,020 people)
Washington, District Of Columbia (694,741 people)
New Orleans, Louisiana (387,417 people)



For the closest cities by population, we show in red the grant categories where saint louis is relatively under-funded, and in green, those where it is relatively over-funded.











    
      
      Grant Source
      Total Funds
      Closest 5: Avg Population
      Closest 5: Fatal Shootings
      Closest 5: Shootings/100k
